review.title: Beliefs and Probability in Bacchus' l.p. Logic: A~3-Valued Logic Solution to Apparent Counter-intuition
review.abstract: Fundamental discrepancy between first order logic and statistical inference (global versus local properties of universe) is shown to be the obstacle for integration of logic and probability in L.p. logic of Bacchus. To overcome the counterintuitiveness of L.p. behaviour, a 3-valued logic is proposed.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The work of Bacchus1 aims at a painless integration of two paradigms of human thought, namely 1) First Order Logic and 2) Statistical Conclusion. (See also8) In a way that avoids all the contradictions that occurred in previous approaches. Nevertheless, the assertion of this work that the L.P. logic of Bacchus1 also fails to achieve its primary goal of becoming the tool for describing knowledge & reasoning in expert systems and other knowledge-based systems. In Section 2, we present some simple examples of fundamental errors of this logic that exploit the counter-intuitiveness of L.P. logic. Section 3 shows a more sophisticated example that points to the weaknesses of L.P. logic. As a remedy, we propose (in a sketchy manner) a different deduction theory that takes into account the gap between the first order way of thinking (global treatment of domains) and the statistical (experimental) sciences (local treatment of domains).
